title: history made at kells connor wi
story: Kells  Connor WI made history in  when their AGM was held in a cattle shed , courtesy of the McAllister family.New President, Rosemary McAllister and her Committee members were elected including Anna Murphy , Eleanor Worthington , Helen Mitchell , Jill Crockard , Wilma Buick , Mary Crothers  Gwen Henson , Olga O’Neill  Iris Manson , Angela Currieand Sharon Graham The competition winners for the Bell Challenge Cup were: st – Maura Ellis, nd – Angela Currie and joint rd Sally Harper  Rosemary Farquhar.Maura Ellis spoke about her avid crafting interests and showed some of the wonderful exhibits made the talented Kells  Connor WI craftswomen.The ladies subsequently attended their annual Christmas dinner in the more luxurious surroundings of the Rosspark Hotel, where they enjoyed a delicious meal and held a quiz afterwards. title: cream of ulster s pipe bands for ballymena competition
story: The Ulster Pipe Band Championships have been confirmed for Mid and East Antrim Borough this July.The prestigious competition will take place at Ballymena Academy on Saturday,  July, and is a collaboration between the Royal Scottish Pipe Band Associationand Mid and East Antrim Borough Council.Up to  pipe bands will compete and be joined by drum majors and Scottish Highland dance classes.The event is a prestigious opportunity for Council, given the competition amongst venues to host across the country.There will be a free shuttle service from the competition venue to the town centre so that pipe band enthusiasts and their families can enjoy a visit to our wonderful local retailers and eateries, while a pop-up performance will provide entertainment on Friday,  July.Admission to the event is free and no tickets are required.Mayor of Mid and East Antrim, Councillor William McCaughey, said:“I am delighted that Council will be delivering this prestigious event during the summer of .“This will be a fantastic day of family entertainment and it is a great honour for Ballymena to host such a wonderful celebration of culture.“All those connected with the pipe band fraternity can be assured of a warm welcome to our borough, and hopefully they will take the time to enjoy the famous Mid and East Antrim hospitality and local places of beauty during their visit over the weekend of  and  July.”At the end of the competition the crowd will be treated to the Grand Finale March Past and Salute to the Chieftain, when all the bands come together and play as one before the prize giving.

title: citizen honour goes to lieutenant stephen lyons
story: LIEUTENANT Stephen Lyons, Detachment Commander of Cullybackey College Detachment, Army Cadet Force has received The British Citizens Award, Certicate of Recognition.Each year The British Citizen Award issue a limited number of Certicates of Recognition to people elevated into essential and key work.  In more recent times the Award has looked to people who since the pandemic first struck, made great efforts and made a signicant impact during these unprecedented times. Lt Lyons joined the Army Cadet Force  years ago after a long career in the reserve army and has since changed the lives of many of his cadets and his certicate is as a result of the positive impact he and his Detachment made through their volunteering efforts. During the pandemic, he was an inspiration for his community, organising assistance of the delivering of food parcels for Cullybackey Community Partnership, and distributing gts to isolated older people at Christmas amongst other local projects.This is not the only award Lt Lyons has received as on July   he had the honour of receiving the Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s daily Points of Light award and then the Lord Lieutenant’s Award in September from Her Majesty’s Lord-Lieutenant of County Antrim, Mr David McCorkell.At the time of becoming the th Point of Light, Lt Lyons said: I feel extremely humbled to be recognised for my efforts by the Prime Ministers Office, especially at this time when so many people are volunteering to help others in such dficult times. I believe this represents all the hard work done by all those adults for young people in the Army Cadet Force.Colonel Adrian Donaldson, MBE, VR, DL, Commandant of the stBattalion Army Cadet Force said of Lt Lyons more recent award: “This is a well deserved award for Lt Stephen Lyons who is a exemplar for the ACF. He epitomises our adult volunteers and their commitment to provide the best possible experience for our youth, as we seek to develop them to their full potential. It follows closely on his personal ‘Points of light’ award from the Prime Minister, and is clear evidence of his dedication and hard work on behalf of all our cadets. Many congratulations and well done!”If you are able to give up an evening a week and want to do something really rewarding with your free time local to you, the Army Cadets could be exactly what you’re looking for. If you’re interested in supporting young people and encouraging them to take part in challenging and inspirational activities go to www.armycadets and sign up today.

title: plans for drop in coffee house at faith mission
story: PLANS are afoot to open a drop-in style cafe in the premises of the Faith Mission Bookshop off High Street in Ballymena.New bookshop manager Andrew Houston explained that they plan to give their shoppers a place to rest their weary legs - and chill out, and forget, for a while at least, about the trouble and stre of every day le!Andrew, in the job for the past couple of months, believes the soon to be refurbished first floor could become quite a haven for those needing just a little time to themselves. “Andwe can help in any way, maybe just by being a place with a listening ear, just let us know - and we will endeavour to assist you in what ever way we can,” outlined Andrew.Yes, we do exist! Meanwhile, the former sales department employee in PowerNI is also very keen to remind the public of the existence of the Faith Mission Bookshop!With this in mind new signs have gone up, one along the top of the shop entrance, and the other on the wall, adjacent to the Tower Shopping Centre ticket machines into the multi storey car-park!“Believe it or not there are people who have called and said in the past they had not known of the shop’s existence! We plan to put this right. Numerous people also said they thought the building was a Church, only, with no book shop,” said Andrew.The bookshop is much, much more than just a bookshop!They have a fantastic array of other gts including Bible covers, drinking water bottles, candles and shopping bags.“We go a good range for all of the family. Come in, give us a visit. And you will be pleasantly surprised at what you will find,” suggested Andrew, formely from Larne, but now living in Ballymena.Meanwhile, the Faith Mission Bookshop hopes to have its cafe, called Trust Coffee, up and running within the next couple of weeks.It is their aim to allow their shoppers to avail of a place of quietness, while enjoying a cuppa or two! “A donation will be made for the coffee, with all proceeds going to our Bible College in Scotland,” explained Andrew.* Faith Mission Bookshops stock a large iety of Christian Books, including Theologies, Missionary Biographies, Devotional books, Commentaries and Bibles as well as large selections of Christian music, both traditional and contemporary.They also stock a good iety of greetings cards and other miscellaneous items. The Ballymena shop, at  High Street, is open am until pm, Monday to Friday.Free customer car parking is available.

title: end of an era as doors close for the last time at windsor presbyterian church
story: Congregation moving to new home in Great Victoria StreetExpandExpandExpandExpandExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseNew dawn: Young members of the congregation enjoy the final service at Belfast’s Windsor Presbyterian Church at the Lisburn Road church which first opened in . Credit: Stephen DavisonReverend Ivan Steen leads the final service. Credit: Stephen DavisonRev Steen and Presbyterian Moderator, Dr David Bruce. Credit: Stephen DavisonWindsor Presbyterian Church dates back to . Credit Stephen DavisonHassan SabahiProfessor Norma Dawson FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueNew dawn: Young members of the congregation enjoy the final service at Belfast’s Windsor Presbyterian Church at the Lisburn Road church which first opened in . Credit: Stephen DavisonAlf McCrearyEmailJanuary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe congregation of Windsor Presbyterian walked in a pilgrimage after their final service on Sunday morning to their new home at Great Victoria Street. They did so with a mixture of sadness but also with hope that great things will develop in their Christian mission nearer the city centre.The Windsor congregation has been forced to leave its beautul late th century building on the Lisburn Road because it cannot pay for the expensive refurbishment of its stonework, dating from . However, the building will be developed as an arts and drama centre by supporters aiming to raise the finance required.The Windsor Church was virtually full for its last service and the large congregation included many current and former members, and former ministers and well-wishers from neighbouring churches.The music was inspiring with much-loved hymns familiar to generations of worshippers, and some people wondered what will happen to the splendid organ which featured for the last time at Windsor in Presbyterian worship. Perhaps it will be used by the new artistic owners.Father Eddie O’Donnell brought best wishes from St. Brigid’s Catholic Church at the other end of Derryvolgie Avenue, as did Mark Houston from the nearby Windsor Baptist Church which moved relatively recently into the old Majestic Cinema on the Lisburn Road.He said “We know how you may be feeling. There will be challenges ahead, but God will be with you.”The Windsor minister the Reverend Ivan Steen preached on the Gospel theme of “new wine in new wineskins”. He said: “The Christian Church and the people of God cannot stand still. Our departure from this building and our pilgrimage to Great Victoria Street is a visual representation of the Christian le on the move.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up The Presbyterian Moderator, the Right Reverend Dr David Bruce said: “Places, including buildings, are important to us, because this is where memories are made. It is likely the things we remember best are connected with places, buildings, gardens and rooms.“We are all on a journey and the landscape continually changes. For Windsor that landscape has changed and accelerated, but as you move on you are being a tutor to others throughout the Presbyterian Church who face the challenges of radical change.”The service which ended with the familiar hymn “Be Thou My Vision” to the traditional Irish melody of Slane was also presented in sign language to cater for the Kinghan Mission for the Deaf which has close connections with the Windsor Church.There were also translations in the Persian language by Hassan Sabahi, a chef who came to Belfast six years ago from Iran. He said: “I have felt at home in Windsor where I was given adult baptism. I am always very happy to help with the service in the Persian language. My fiancée Mina is still living in Iran but we are working to try to ensure that she will join me here within the next few months.”The Windsor congregation includes a number of refugees and asylum seekers. A young Mongolian woman Demi Mijiddorj Tenuun was at Sunday’s service with her son Tumurchuder . She was a laboratory chemist in Mongolia and came to Belfast six years ago. She said: “When I came I spoke no English and had no family, but the people of Windsor Church became my wider family. If I had to leave this church on my own I would be sad, but I am leaving with my Windsor family and I am leaving with hope for the future.”Norma Dawson, an Emeritus Professor at Queen’s University, has been a Windsor elder for over  years. She said: “Today is bittersweet. I am sad at leaving but I am also grateful that the people of Great Victoria Street Church are being so warm and welcoming to us.”Cecil Graham, an elder for over  years, said: “I will also be sad at leaving but the move to Great Victoria Street will provide a greater base for outreach nearer the city centre”The congregation included Tom Hartley, a former Sinn Fein Councillor and Lord Mayor of Belfast who has a special interest in Presbyterian Churches. It is estimated that  of these in Belfast have closed since .A former Presbyterian Moderator, the Very Reverend Dr John Dunlop who was also at the service, said: “It is a sad day because Windsor is closing. It is such a beautul building on a great site, but it is also a positive move which will provide a place of worship and of meeting from many immigrants and asylum seekers from all parts of the city.”The Reverend Steen added: “We are also near the Kinghan Mission in Botanic Avenue which is now the most international part of the city.”At the Great Victoria Street Church later on there was joy and celebration as people from both congregations shared a barbecue and light refreshments,The minister, the Reverend William Harkness, said: “I am very excited. This feels just right and we welcome the Windsor people with open arms, like two parts coming together.”Most ReadIan Paisley gives we Fiona a £k pay rise for part-time jobOusted Jim Wells fears he the can: Andrew Power who launched a lager in AustraliaRalph HewittTwitterEmailJanuary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailA limited edition lager celebrating the centenary of Northern Ireland has been voted one of Australia’s top  craft beers for  — and the Co Down expat behind it now has plans for a brew paying tribute to Sandy Row in memory of his father.Bangor man Andrew Power launched Six Counties Craft Beer in June and said it was “awesome” to see it finish in the top  of the Great Australasian Beer SpecTAPularhottest new brews of .Read MoreSix Counties Craft Beer: Northern Ireland centenary lager in running for top   Australian beersGoing up against thousands of other beers, Six Counties finished th overall and was placed th in the new craft beer section following the public vote.Since the GABS poll began in , lager lovers in Australia are asked to select, in order of preference, their five favourite craft beers of the year.Andrew, who moved Down Under in  and lives in Brisbane, owns Ulster Distributions, which distributes beer, wines and other products to bottle shops and bars across south east Queensland.After Andrew spoke to the brewers at Helios about creating the limited edition Six Counties, work quickly progressed to bring together the .% strength lager, which has been described as hoppy with lemon and citrus notes.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up The hard work paid off and Andrew is now aiming to release a Sandy Row Pale Ale later this year in memory of his father.Billy Power , who passed away from Parkinson’s disease in July, lived in Bangor but was originally from Sandy Row in south Belfast.Andrew said some of the proceeds raised from Sandy Row Pale Ale will go to a Parkinson’s disease charity in Brisbane.“It will be the follow up to Six Counties,” said Andrew, who is currently in discussions with a number of breweries about creating Sandy Row Pale Ale.“Six Counties is very unique obviously with the centenary year and now we’ve moved on to  so we’re looking at doing a Sandy Row Pale Ale, which is planned to be released later this year.“My father passed away from Parkinson’s last year and he was from Sandy Row and I have a lot of family there so it’s going to be a tribute to that part of Belfast and obviously my dad as well.“We’ll put Sandy Row on the map Down Under.”On Six Counties’ success in the GABS festival, Andrew said he was proud to see it do so well in a country as big as Australia.“We finished th in new craft beers and I really don’t know how many breweries there is across Australia,” he added. “It would be in the thousands.“Here in Brisbane alone there are a number of big boys and  or  on the Sunshine Coast and the Gold Coast has a couple of big ones down there too.“Every year they#re always looking for new releases and with a wee small guy like Helios taking an idea that I had, it was pretty satisfying to get the result.”Celebrating Northern Ireland’s centenary year Down Under was also a highlight for Andrew as it gave him the opportunity to let people know about the country and its history.He said the support Six Counties received from the expat community and locals was overwhelming.“A lot of local people really enjoyed the beer and it became one of the brewery favourites,” Andrew explained. “It was on tap in the brewery for a number of months and a lot of people had the opportunity to try it.“By then people started asking me questions about Six Counties, Northern Ireland and the centenary year so it was nice to be able to enlighten people and educate them on our wee country.Finishing th overall isn#t bad. There were about  dferent breweries in there and they all had  or  beers in each so it was pretty good.”Canberra#s Bentspoke’s Crankshaft American IPA was voted Australia’s favourite craft beer in what was described as the closest finish in the history of the GABS Hottest  Aussie Craft Beers poll. title: ni smoking ban what legal changes are coming into effect on tuesday
story: Stock image FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueStock imageNiamh CampbellTwitterEmailJanuary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailA ban on smoking in vehicles carrying children is to come into full legal effect across Northern Ireland on Tuesday.From February , it will also be an offence for a driver to smoke in a private vehicle when there is more than one person in the vehicle and the vehicle is enclosed, orthey permit someone  to smoke while children under the age of  are present.The Executive has noted that a vehicle is still enclosed eventhe windows are down and or the doors are open.Read MoreCharity welcomes NI ban on smoking in cars carrying childrenHowever, the rules do not apply to motorcycles, or to convertible cars when the roof is completely down.An exemption is permitted for caravans and motor homes, as the primary purpose of these vehicles is for accommodation, therefore they are only required to be smoke-free when they are on the road.Northern Ireland is the last UK region to make the move, with England and Wales implementing the ban in . Scotland and the Republic of Ireland followed suit the following year.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Tuesday will also see new legislation prohibit sales of e-cigarettesto under-s. Businesses that break this rule will be given a fixed penalty notice of £, or a maximum fine of £,prosecuted and convicted by a court.From Tuesday, those found smoking in smoke-free private vehicles will receive a fixed penalty notice of £for the person smoking, or a maximum fine of £,prosecuted and convicted by a court.Drivers permitting others to smoke in a smoke-free private vehicle will receive a fixed penalty notice of £, or a maximum fine of £,prosecuted and convicted by a court.Health Minister Robin Swann urged smokers to quit ahead of the new regulations being introduced.“It’s important that smokers are aware of the new regulations and realise thatyou smoke in a car while a child is there, oryou’re the driver and you allow someone to smoke in these circumstances, you will be committing an offence which carries a hefty penalty,” he said.Naomi Thompson, Health Improvement Manager at Cancer Focus NI welcomed the changes.This is a signicant move to a tobacco-free Northern Ireland. We firmly believe that these new laws will protect children’s health,” she said. We have already protected adults in workplaces and public places from second-hand smoke and it’s high time we gave our young people the same protection. It’ll also reduce their perception that smoking is normal behaviour. We know that children who regularly see adults smoke are more likely to try smoking.”It became illegal to smoke in any pub, restaurant, nightclub, and most workplaces and work vehicles, in Northern Ireland and across the UK in .The latest ban follows other measures to steer young people in Northern Ireland away from smoking in recent years.These include the ban of tobacco sales in vending machines the ban of tobacco displays in shops tougher sanctions on retailers caught selling tobacco to children standardised packaging and a ban on selling cigarettes in packs of ten.Ms Thompson also noted that “most e-cigarettes contain nicotine and nicotine is highly addictive, so it makes sense to limit access to e-cigarettes for under s”.There are concerns that young people who start vaping and become addicted to nicotine, may also become tobacco smokers, so we see this legislation working not only to reduce usage of e-cigarettes among young people, but potentially reduce the number of young people who ultimately take up smoking,” the charity worker continued.She said there are currently , deaths caused by tobacco in Northern Ireland every year, along with thousands affected by cancer, respiratory and other smoking related illnesses.Most ReadIan Paisley gives we Fiona a £k pay rise for part-time jobOusted Jim Wells fears he will have to sell home to pay for we’s careIn AMFacebookTwitterEmailThe public will be “rightly concerned” that £.m has been provided to  businesses for fossil fuel and mineral extraction in Northern Ireland in the last five years by Invest NI, it has been warned.It comes as Economy Minster Gordon Lyons prepares to bring proposals to the Executive on petroleum licensing here.Concerns have been raised over the years regarding the impact large-scale mining, fracking and other forms of mineral extraction would have on the environment here.According to a recent written answer to an Assembly question, Invest NI — under its ‘mining and quarrying’ classication for businesses — has provided  offers of assistance to  businesses in this sector in the last five years.Read MoreFormer BBC chair Sir Michael Lyons to head up strategic review into Invest NI“The total value of support offered was £.m, which will leverage a total investment of £.m,” Economy Minister Gordon Lyons said.Green Party MLA Rachel Woods said that as the environmental impact of mining and fossil fuel extraction in Northern Ireland comes under increasing scrutiny, the public will “rightly be concerned” to learn that Invest NI has offered support worth over £.m of public money to companies involved in these “destructive” practices.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “Precious metals, oil and gas should be kept in the ground. Mining, drilling and fracking risks the destruction of our environment through contributing to our already high emissions, and polluting our water further,” she said.“The five-party Executive must step up to represent the community, by supporting the anti-mining campaign and ensure that mining and fossil fuel extraction come to an end.“I have tabled an amendment in the Assembly to introduce a legislative ban on the exploration and extraction of fossil fuels in Northern Ireland.“Fracking is a dangerous and environmentally harmful practice, which should have no place in Northern Ireland as we make a just transition to a net-zero future.”People Before Profit MLA Gerry Carroll added: “There are clearly mixed messages and policy coming from the Stormont Executive in relation to climate change. “On the one hand the Executive makes occasional good soundings about climate change but then continually implements policies that specically destroy the environment.“This is a clear example of that in practice. “There is countless evidence of the harm and environmental damage committed by the extractive industry, yet the minister has ignored those warnings and allowed millions to go directly into the coffers of extractive companies.”Invest NI said: “An experienced Invest NI assessment  considers all aspects of a project against Invest NI’s intervention principles and the assessment process is rigorous. In addition, applications are assessed on the basis of the level of innovation, the potential for commercialisation and the economic impact of the project.”The Department for the Economy said it is undertaking a review of both minerals and petroleum licensing policies to ensure that the regimes remain fit for purpose.“As regards oil and gas, independent research has been undertaken to consider the environmental, social and economic impacts of onshore petroleum exploration and production in Northern Ireland,” the department said.“Informed by this research and other relevant international studies, a range of policy options for the future of the petroleum licensing system are being considered. “Given the controversial and cross cutting nature of this topic the options will be presented to the Executive. “The minister hopes to bring options to the Executive soon for agreement of a preferred policy option which will then be subject to public consultation.”The department said the review of minerals licensing is being taken forward separately to that for oil and gas and research is being undertaken into the economic, societal and environmental impacts of mineral exploration and mining in Northern Ireland. story: New PSNI unorm launched on January . Credit: PSNI FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueNew PSNI unorm launched on January . Credit: PSNINiamh CampbellTwitterEmailJanuary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailPSNI officers in communities across Northern Ireland will begin wearing a dferent unorm from Monday, which will consist of a new style of trouser and a bottle green top to replace the white shirt and tie.It is the first time the police unorm has changed since the PSNI was officially formed in .Chief Constable Simon Byrne unveiled the new attire, which comes after trials of ious versions of the unorm and a public consultation.New operational unorm launch day @PoliceServiceNI @PoliceFedforNI Another step in our approach to a more modern Service . pic ywjbJcjxdN— Simon ByrneJanuary , “You will remember that  officers from a range of operational positions and locations took part in a three-month trial, and we sought your views when we conducted three social media surveys last year,” said Mr Byrne.Read MoreNew sports-style unorms could cost the PSNI over £m“The previous unorm has been in existence since the formation of the Police Service of Northern Ireland.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up It served our officers well, but it is right that we reviewed how effective it was  years on.”Mr Byrne added that reviewing the unorm was an “important part of our commitment” to ensuring PSNI officers and staff are provided with a safe, comfortable and high quality unorm in order to allow them to do their job.“The new unorm will be worn by officers up to the rank of Chief Superintendent,” he continued.“It is important that we equip our frontline officers with professional, modern work wear, which is fit for purpose. I am committed to ensuring that the unorm is practical and comfortable in support of our officers as they work to prevent, detect and target crime in our communities today.From today, officers will be wearing a new style of trouser and bottle green top to replace the white shirt and tie. It is important that our officers are equipped with a practical unorm as they prevent, detect and target crime in our communities pic ncJqpHICyA— Police Service NIJanuary , “A lot of work has gone into planning and seeking feedback around the new unorm. Our officers work at the heart of communities and, therefore it was also fitting that we listened to what communities thought during the pilot phase.Officers were consulted and feedback was also sought from key stakeholders, including the Police Federation, the Northern Ireland Policing Board, and Police and Community Safety Partnerships.“I believe the new unorm will help us to enhance the visible, accessible and responsive service we seek to provide to the community.”Related topicsPolice Service of Northern IrelandMore On Police Service of Northern IrelandResidents evacuated in early Credit: Clf DonaldsonJim Clarken of OxfamCaoimhe de Barra of Trocaire FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueAndy Mayhew of PraxisAndrew MaddenTwitterEmailJanuary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailSome charity bosses in Northern Ireland are drawing down salaries topping £,-a-year, it can be revealed today.The head of mental health charity Praxis Care, Andy Mayhew, receives between £, and £, annually.This is around the same salary as Stormont’s First and Deputy First Ministers — who received £, each last year.In a special investigation, the Belfastasked  leading charities how much their Northern Ireland head, or most senior employee here, earned –  of them responded.The remaining charities did not respond to requests for the salary information.Of those who disclosed the salaries,  bosses received more than £, annually and at least four took home in excess of £,.According to the Charity Commission, which regulates charities here, there are more than , charities registered in Northern Ireland.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up While some of these are large, multi-national, all-Ireland or UK-wide organisations with hundreds of employees, many are very small and only have a handful of staff.Other big earners, aside from Praxis’ Andy Mayhew, were Oxfam’s all-Ireland chief executive Jim Clarken, who receives €,a year, and Trocaire’s all-Ireland chief executive Caoimhe de Barra, who normally takes home around €, , however due to Covid this was reduced to €,in the   financial year.Oxfam commented in their response: “As part of his role Jim Clarken is also a member of the Board of Oxfam International, which means sharing strategic responsibility for the entire Oxfam global network in more than  countries. The CEO’s salary is set by the remuneration and performance committee which is made up of three members of the board, known as the Council. All of our board members are volunteers.”Unicef Ireland’s director, Peter Power, has an annual salary of €, , while St Vincent de Paul’s national director , Andy Heffernan, brings home between €, and €, Agnes Lunny is the chief executive of learning disability charity Positive Futures, based in Northern Ireland, and Positive Futures Ireland, based in the Republic.Her combined salary for both roles is £, annually.In her response to this newspaper request, Ms Lunny said: “My average working week across both roles is + hours, more often than not  hours. That puts my hourly pay at between £ and £.“My salary was recently increased following a benchmarking exercise against similar roles in Health  Social Care.”All-Ireland wellbeing charity Inspire’s chief executive, Kerry Anthony, has an annual salary of between £, and £,. An Inspire spokesperson said: “You will see from our accounts that our income mostly comes from contracts for services with very little coming from donations from the public. Any donations we do get from the public to support our work go straight to the projects for which they are raised and don’t contribute to the pay of our CEO.”Ulster Unionist MLA Andy Allen, a member of Stormont’s Communities Committee, said he can understand why some may be concerned by charity bosses taking in large salaries, however the signicant amount of work they undertake must be taken into account.“The structure and complexity of modern charities require leadership and ability at the highest levels to ensure the organisation is managed effectively to deliver vital support services for their beneficiaries,” he said.“While I understand fully the public concern that salaries of some charity chief executives are over £,, it is important to recognise the experience and skills required to run an organisation that employs hundreds of people, manages millions of pounds of public money and donations — delivering vital services to our most needy and vulnerable.If an inidual could earn more in a similar position in the private sector, as is the case in many of these examples, then how can our charities attract the best and most qualied leaders to ensure services to those most in need are deliveredthey are not offering a comparable salary that recognises the skills and experience needed ”In December , it emerged that the then-Communities Minister Caral Ni Chuilin had commissioned an independent review of the Charity Commission, following a report by senior civil servant Jonathan Baume looking at how the Department for Communities handled complaints in relation to the Commission.Responding to an Assembly question about the Baume report’s recommendations by TUV leader Jim Allister at the time, Ms Ni Chuilin said: “The former Head of the Civil Servicecommissioned a review into how the Department for Communities had handled a number of complaints from a member of the public in relation to the Charity Commission.“HOCS asked my Department to respond to the suggestions set out in the review. These are currently being progressed, including consideration of the Department’s role as the custodian of charity regulation law and policy and sponsor for the Commission.“The Department’s Head of Governance has also written to the Chief Commissioner to seek assurances in relation to matters highlighted in the Review.“In order to restore public confidence in a system that has undoubtedly been damaged, I have also decided to commission an independent review of charity regulation including a review of the performance of the Charity Commission in its role as statutory regulator.”Related title: edinburgh newcastle rail line closed due to storm corrie
story: Rail services between Edinburgh and Newcastle are suspended due to Storm Corrie, causing major disruption to passengers  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueRail services between Edinburgh and Newcastle are suspended due to Storm Corrie, causing major disruption to passengers By Neil Lancefield, PA Transport CorrespondentJanuary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailRail passenger face major disruption as services between Edinburgh and Newcastle are suspended due to Storm Corrie.The line was closed on Monday morning because of strong winds and heavy rain across the east coast of Scotland and the north-east of England.Affected operators include London North Eastern Railway, CrossCountry and TransPennine Express.⚠️Good Morning. Our teams have been carrying out safety checks throughout the night due to #StormCorrie. With daylight, we will inspect again with a view to clearing and making the lines affected safe for traffic.Please check in with your service provider for updates.— Network Rail ScotlandJanuary , Network Rail said it was carrying out safety checks in a bid to reopen the line.These include monitoring overhead electric wires to ensure they have not been damaged in the severe weather, and running trains to check for debris on tracks.The organisation said its staff have faced “an exceptionally challenging weekend with two signicant storms bringing severe weather”.⚠️ #LNERUpdate Today, st January, no services will run between #Newcastle and #Scotland until . due to the severe weather.Please, continue to check here for further updates throughout the day https:t.co fUHBtQxa. pic lWsazctFa— London North Eastern RailwayJanuary , Storm Malik caused disruption on Saturday, before the arrival of Storm Corrie on Sunday.Passenger trains between Edinburgh and Newcastle will initially be required to run at slower speeds than normal even once the line reopens, leading to further delays to journeys.Much of the ScotRail network has been affected by the severe weather.The operator warned passengers on Monday that it has only been able to arrange “very limited replacement transport”. title: uae intercepts yemen missile as israeli president visits
story: Israeli president Isaac Herzog, centre, and First Lady Michal Herzog are received by UAE Foreign Minister, Sheikh Abdullah bin Zayed Al Nahyan in Abu Dhabi  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueIsraeli president Isaac Herzog, centre, and First Lady Michal Herzog are received by UAE Foreign Minister, Sheikh Abdullah bin Zayed Al Nahyan in Abu Dhabi By Jon Gambrell, APJanuary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThe United Arab Emirates has intercepted a ballistic missile fired by Yemen’s Houthi rebels as the Israeli president visits the country, authorities said – the third such attack in recent weeks.The attack during Isaac Herzog’s visit only fuels the ongoing tensions affecting the wider Persian Gulf, which has seen a series of
